aws::graph::propositions: # Aviation Accident Report for Cessna 182 in Joseph, Oregon
The accident occurred on August 1, 2012, at 17:15 Local time.
The accident occurred in Joseph, Oregon.
The aircraft involved was a Cessna 182.
The aircraft registration was N5418B.
The Cessna 182 was a tailwheel-equipped airplane.
The defining event of the accident was nose over/nose down.
The flight was conducted under Part 91: General aviation - Personal.
The accident number was WPR12CA353.
The aircraft sustained substantial damage.
There was 1 person involved in the accident.
No injuries were reported in the accident.
The pilot experienced gusting crosswinds during landing on runway 33.
The pilot applied the brakes in an attempt to maintain control during the landing roll.
The airplane nosed over after the pilot applied the brakes.
The firewall was substantially damaged.
Both wings were substantially damaged.
The ailerons were substantially damaged.
The flaps were substantially damaged.
The vertical stabilizer was substantially damaged.
The wind was from 280 degrees at 3 to 6 knots.
The wind was gusting to 8 to 10 knots.
The pilot reported no mechanical failures.
The pilot reported no malfunctions that would have precluded normal flight.
The National Transportation Safety Board determined the probable cause of the accident.
The probable cause was the pilot's excessive use of brakes during the landing roll in a gusting crosswind.
The excessive use of brakes resulted in a noseover.
The findings included incorrect use/operation of landing gear brakes system.
The findings included pilot issues with aircraft control.
The findings included environmental issues with crosswind response/compensation.
The findings included environmental issues with gusts response/compensation.

text:
# Aviation Investigation Final Report

## Location:
Joseph, Oregon

## Date & Time: 
August 1, 2012, 17:15 Local

## Aircraft:
Cessna 182

## Defining Event:
Nose over/nose down

## Flight Conducted Under:
Part 91: General aviation - Personal

## Accident Number:
WPR12CA353

## Registration:
N5418B

## Aircraft Damage:
Substantial

## Injuries:
1 None

## Analysis
The pilot reported that, during the landing on runway 33, he experienced gusting crosswinds. In an attempt to maintain control during the landing roll, the pilot applied the brakes, and the tailwheel-equipped airplane nosed over. The firewall, both wings, including the ailerons and flaps, and the vertical stabilizer were substantially damaged. The pilot reported that the wind was from 280 degrees at 3 to 6 knots gusting to 8 to 10 knots. The pilot reported no mechanical failures or malfunctions that would have precluded normal flight.

## Probable Cause and Findings
The National Transportation Safety Board determines the probable cause(s) of this accident to be: The pilot's excessive use of brakes during the landing roll in a gusting crosswind, which resulted in a noseover.

## Findings
| | |
|-|-|
| Aircraft | Landing gear brakes system - Incorrect use/operation |
| Personnel issues | Aircraft control - Pilot |
| Environmental issues | Crosswind - Response/compensation |
| Environmental issues | Gusts - Response/compensation |

---
